hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with romesco that's right when they

do the Mount Rushmore of cold sauces
romesco will take its place next to

the fourth one would be no not ranch

dressing
maybe ketchup but we can argue about the

the point is romesco is definitely up

there and by the way if you're thinking
I already posted this I sort of did a

very long time ago but it wasn't for
this channel and it was actually for a

website that's gone out of business so
I've wanted to post this new version for

a while and it actually starts exactly
like the old version by fire roasting

some red peppers which I'm going to do
on top of this stove over an open flame

and of course your other options for
this would be do them outside on the

grill or in the oven under the broiler
but for me while it might make a little

bit of a mess this is the fastest and
easiest method and one thing to keep in

mind here a lot of instructions say do
this until the skin turns black which

actually happens relatively quickly by
just getting the outside black is not

the same thing as fire roasting right
not only are we burning off the skin

here but we also want to be cooking the
pepper so yes we do want these blackened

all over but we also want to cook them
until they soften up and steam starts to

come out okay so phase one here is just
keep turning them around until all that

skin blackens up but then phase two is
to continue until they're actually

cooked through and again the dead
giveaway is that they soften up and

steam starts to pour out which hopefully
you're gonna get a pretty good look at

as I pull that one off the back all
right you can see that steam coming out

and the pepper has clearly softened up
and what we'll do once we think our

peppers have roasted long enough is
transfer those ánewá Bowl and then we'll

want to cover that quickly with a plate
or some plastic and we'll just let those

sit there steaming until they reach room
temp at which point they should be very

very easy to peel and then what we'll do
after we proper the pepper is head back

to the stove where we're gonna toast
some garlic in our olive oil and we'll

be doing that over medium heat although
I do like to start in a cold pan so

we'll combine our whole garlic cloves
and our oil and go ahead and turn on the

heat
it simply toast that garlic in the oil

for about three minutes or so or until
the outsides just start to turn a little

bit golden brown right not a lot golden
brown just a little golden brown and as

you can see I do like
keep those clothes moving in the oil

pretty much constantly and while these
are not gonna cook through in just three

minutes or so we are taking that sharp
raw edge off and we're hopefully gonna

end up with something halfway between
roasted garlic in raw garlic and then

what we'll do once our garlic cloves
have been very lightly browned is remove

those with a slotted spoon to a ramekin
since we want to leave all the oil in

that pan because next up we're gonna use
it to toast our bread cubes if we're

using bread
okay the bread here is optional whoops I

got a cube plot there we go but anyway
as I was saying using bread here is up

to you I mean you are after all the
Kurtis Blow of your romesco and if you

can't eat bread those are the breaks but
you don't have to use it here it will

still come out beautifully but having
said that I do like to include them

because I do think it improves the
texture and if we are gonna use them

we'll go ahead and toast those in this
oil still over medium heat until they

reach a golden brown and once that's
happened we'll go ahead and pull that

off the heat and that is pretty much it
for the initial prep although we do

still need to seed and peel our peppers
which as I mentioned should be super

easy at this point since they'd been
steaming here in this bowl although I do

highly recommend peeling and seeing
these in the sink under some running

water which is exactly what I did and
sure some people say you lose too much

flavor that way but those people are
crazy

you don't Plus trying to peel that skin
off without any water is gonna take you

like two hours so suit yourself but if
you're keeping score at home I do like

to use running water and then what we'll
do once our peppers have been seeded and

peeled is go ahead and give them a rough
chop by simply cutting them in strips

one way and then we'll turn them and cut
them across into cubes like this and the

only reason we're doing this is so that
they blend a little more evenly and a

little easier in the food processor so
for me it's worth the extra minute and

then once our peppers have a big cube
we'll go ahead and transfer those into

the bowl of our food processor at which
point we go ahead and add our garlic

cloves as well as our toasted bread
cubes along with any and all associated

oil which brings us to our last major
ingredients and that would be some

almonds and I like to use roasted
almonds but you can also use raw or

blanched they'll all work just giving
slightly different results

and what we'll do once this has been
nutted is finish it off with some sherry

vinegar as well as a nice big spoon of
Spanish hot smoked paprika or the pepper

eek of your choice you're welcome hungry
and for a little extra heat I also added

a little touch of cayenne and last but
not least we will add a giant pinch of

salt and that's it we'll go ahead and
take that over and process it by pulsing

on and off until it's this course or as
smooth as we want and believe it or not

that's it other than adjusting for final
seasoning our romesco sauce is done and

right here you're gonna get a great look
at my final texture which for me is not

too thick not too thin
in other words perfect and if you wanted

at this point you can grill up a whole
bunch of vegetables or fish or meat and

start enjoying this fabulous condiment
slash sauce but I highly recommend you

don't since I think by wrapping this up
and pop it in the fridge for one day the

flavors really really develop a lot more
alright I can't prove it it's only

anecdotal evidence but that's what I
think so of course we're gonna give it a

taste or two but I do highly recommend
wrapping this up and give it a little

time to age in the fridge which is
exactly what I did before transferring

some of it into a little serving dish
and because I am contractually obligated

to take some pictures I finished with
some toasted almonds and a few sliced

green onions and lastly a little tiny

little sparkle but anyway I went ahead

before finally enjoying a spoon on a

one of the best ways to enjoy it
